docs.text: Welcome to MkDocs For full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Commands mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit. Project layout mkdocs.yml # The configuration file. docs/ index.md # The documentation homepage. ... # Other markdown pages, images and other files.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: .vega-actions a { margin-right: 12px; color: #757575; font-weight: normal; font-size: 13px; } .error { color: red; } test page in this section i will test a couple of pluggings used in this website latex \begin{align*} \text{maximize}& \sum_{s\in S} \ \left[\text{min}_{a \in A \setminus a^*} (\mathbf{P}_{a^*,s} - \mathbf{P}_{a,s}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R}\right] - \lambda ||\mathbf{R}||_1 \newline \text{s.t. }& (\mathbf{P}_{a^*} - \mathbf{P}_{a}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R} \succeq 0, \forall a \in A \setminus a^{*} \end{align*} \begin{align*} \text{maximize}& \sum_{s\in S} \ \left[\text{min}_{a \in A \setminus a^*} (\mathbf{P}_{a^*,s} - \mathbf{P}_{a,s}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R}\right] - \lambda ||\mathbf{R}||_1 \newline \text{s.t. }& (\mathbf{P}_{a^*} - \mathbf{P}_{a}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R} \succeq 0, \forall a \in A \setminus a^{*} \end{align*} figure citation I want to cite this 1 table Parameter Type Description foo string A parameter that does something. bar int A parameter that does something. baz URI Required. docs.text:
PyMdown Extensions Admonition The following types: attention, caution, danger, error, hint, important, note, tip, and warning are included but you can specify whatever you'd like (more details can be seen in here ) Example Admonition Markdown !!! danger highlight blink "Don't try this at home" ... Html < div class = "admonition danger highlight blink" > < p class = "admonition-title" > Don't try this at home </ p > < p > ... </ p > </ div > Output Danger Don't try this at home Detail This helps to make admonitions collapsible. Use ???+ if you want to start a detail block that is defaulted to be open Example Details Markdown ???+ note "Open styled details" ??? danger "Nested details!" And more content again. Html < details class = "note" open = "" > < summary > Open styled details </ summary > < details class = "danger" > < summary > Nested details! </ summary > < p > And more content again. </ p > </ details > </ details > Output Open styled details Nested details! And more content again. Tabbed Example Tabs Markdown === "Tab 1" Markdown **content**. Multiple paragraphs. === "Tab 2" More Markdown **content**. - list item a - list item b Html < div class = "tabbed-set" data-tabs = "2:2" > < input checked = "checked" id = "__tabbed_2_1" name = "__tabbed_2" type = "radio" > < label for = "__tabbed_2_1" > Tab 1 </ label > < div class = "tabbed-content" > < p > Markdown < strong > content </ strong > . </ p > < p > Multiple paragraphs. </ p > </ div > < input id = "__tabbed_2_2" name = "__tabbed_2" type = "radio" > < label for = "__tabbed_2_2" > Tab 2 </ label > < div class = "tabbed-content" > < p > More Markdown < strong > content </ strong > . </ p > < ul > < li > list item a </ li > < li > list item b </ li > </ ul > </ div > </ div > Output Tab 1 Markdown content . Multiple paragraphs. Tab 2 More Markdown content . list item a list item b SuperFences Injecting Classes Markdown ```{.python .extra-class linenums="1"} import hello_world ``` HTML < table class = "extra-class highlighttable" > < tr > < td class = "linenos" > < div class = "linenodiv" > < pre >< span ></ span > 1 </ pre > </ div > </ td > < td class = "code" > < div class = "extra-class highlight" > < pre >< span ></ span >< code >< span cv ></ td >< td class = "code" >< div class = "extra-class highlight" >< pre >< span ></ span >< code >< span class = "kn" > import </ span > < spanlass =" kn " > import </ span > < span class = "nn" > hello_world </ span > 
 </ code ></ pre > </ div > 
 </ td > </ tr > </ table > Output 1 import hello_world Markdown ```math  egin{align*} 	ext{maximize}& \sum_{s\in S} \ \left[	ext{min}_{a \in A \setminus a^*} (\mathbf{P}_{a^*,s} - \mathbf{P}_{a,s}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R}ight] - \lambda ||\mathbf{R}||_1 
ewline 	ext{s.t. }& (\mathbf{P}_{a^*} - \mathbf{P}_{a}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R} \succeq 0,  orall a \in A \setminus a^{*} \end{align*} ``` Output  egin{align*} 	ext{maximize}& \sum_{s\in S} \ \left[	ext{min}_{a \in A \setminus a^*} (\mathbf{P}_{a^*,s} - \mathbf{P}_{a,s}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R}ight] - \lambda ||\mathbf{R}||_1 
ewline 	ext{s.t. }& (\mathbf{P}_{a^*} - \mathbf{P}_{a}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R} \succeq 0,  orall a \in A \setminus a^{*} \end{align*} Mark 🏪 some convenient markup that are available to use while editing markdown documents Markdown Example Description ==This was marked== This was marked mark html tag ^^This was inserted^^ This was inserted ins html tag ~~This was deleted~~ This was deleted del html tag H~2~0 H 2 0 sub html tag A^T^A A T A sup html tag
docs.title: PyMdown

docs.text: The following types: attention, caution, danger, error, hint, important, note, tip, and warning are included but you can specify whatever you'd like (more details can be seen in here ) Example Admonition Markdown !!! danger highlight blink "Don't try this at home" ... Html < div class = "admonition danger highlight blink" > < p class = "admonition-title" > Don't try this at home </ p > < p > ... </ p > </ div > Output Danger Don't try this at home

docs.text: This helps to make admonitions collapsible. Use ???+ if you want to start a detail block that is defaulted to be open Example Details Markdown ???+ note "Open styled details" ??? danger "Nested details!" And more content again. Html < details class = "note" open = "" > < summary > Open styled details </ summary > < details class = "danger" > < summary > Nested details! </ summary > < p > And more content again. </ p > </ details > </ details > Output Open styled details Nested details! And more content again.

docs.text: Example Tabs Markdown === "Tab 1" Markdown **content**. Multiple paragraphs. === "Tab 2" More Markdown **content**. - list item a - list item b Html < div class = "tabbed-set" data-tabs = "2:2" > < input checked = "checked" id = "__tabbed_2_1" name = "__tabbed_2" type = "radio" > < label for = "__tabbed_2_1" > Tab 1 </ label > < div class = "tabbed-content" > < p > Markdown < strong > content </ strong > . </ p > < p > Multiple paragraphs. </ p > </ div > < input id = "__tabbed_2_2" name = "__tabbed_2" type = "radio" > < label for = "__tabbed_2_2" > Tab 2 </ label > < div class = "tabbed-content" > < p > More Markdown < strong > content </ strong > . </ p > < ul > < li > list item a </ li > < li > list item b </ li > </ ul > </ div > </ div > Output Tab 1 Markdown content . Multiple paragraphs. Tab 2 More Markdown content . list item a list item b

Injecting Classes Markdown ```{.python .extra-class linenums="1"} import hello_world ``` HTML < table class = "extra-class highlighttable" > < tr > < td class = "linenos" > < div class = "linenodiv" > < pre >< span ></ span > 1 </ pre > </ div > </ td > < td class = "code" > < div class = "extra-class highlight" > < pre >< span ></ span >< code >< span cv ></ td >< td class = "code" >< div class = "extra-class highlight" >< pre >< span ></ span >< code >< span class = "kn" > import </ span > < spanlass =" kn " > import </ span > < span class = "nn" > hello_world </ span > 
 </ code ></ pre > </ div > 
 </ td > </ tr > </ table > Output 1 import hello_world Markdown ```math  egin{align*} 	ext{maximize}& \sum_{s\in S} \ \left[	ext{min}_{a \in A \setminus a^*} (\mathbf{P}_{a^*,s} - \mathbf{P}_{a,s}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R}ight] - \lambda ||\mathbf{R}||_1 
ewline 	ext{s.t. }& (\mathbf{P}_{a^*} - \mathbf{P}_{a}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R} \succeq 0,  orall a \in A \setminus a^{*} \end{align*} ``` Output  egin{align*} 	ext{maximize}& \sum_{s\in S} \ \left[	ext{min}_{a \in A \setminus a^*} (\mathbf{P}_{a^*,s} - \mathbf{P}_{a,s}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R}ight] - \lambda ||\mathbf{R}||_1 
ewline 	ext{s.t. }& (\mathbf{P}_{a^*} - \mathbf{P}_{a}) (\mathbf{I} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_{a^*})^{-1} \mathbf{R} \succeq 0,  orall a \in A \setminus a^{*} \end{align*}

docs.text: 🏪 some convenient markup that are available to use while editing markdown documents Markdown Example Description ==This was marked== This was marked mark html tag ^^This was inserted^^ This was inserted ins html tag ~~This was deleted~~ This was deleted del html tag H~2~0 H 2 0 sub html tag A^T^A A T A sup html tag
docs.title: Mark

docs.text: Agent Based Model Evaluate A Trading Strategy Balch et al 1 A key weakness of Market Replay is that the simulated market does not substantially adapt to or respond to the presence of the experimental strategy…Most professional investors, hedge funds, investment institutions and banks prefer to test(backtest) trading strategies in simulation before "going live" with funds at risk. They have compared two important but distinct methods for evaluating a trading strategy: backtesting and Interactive Agent-Based Simulation (IABS). Both strategies are implemented in their open-source ABIDES framework. Question Investigate the impact of a large market buy order by requiring agent to place market buy order sized at 200% of best ask size. This experiment is repeated 100 100 times at different times of day (so statistics are averaged over 100 100 ). Data Between 09:45:00 - 09:53:15 (100 \times 5 \ sec.) 09:45:00 - 09:53:15 (100 \times 5 \ sec.) with order placed every 5 \ sec. 5 \ sec. providing 100 100 buys and 100 100 sells. Agents Experiment Agent acts by a candidate trading strategy. Exchange Agent maintains the order book data Market Replay Agent place limit orders scheduled by historical order book data Market Impact Results Backtest Agent-Based Simulation Tucker Hybinette Balch, Mahmoud Mahfouz, Joshua Lockhart, Maria Hybinette, and David Byrd. How to evaluate trading strategies: single agent market replay or multiple agent interactive simulation? arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.12010 , 2019. ↩
docs.title: Agent Model

docs.text: Balch et al 1 A key weakness of Market Replay is that the simulated market does not substantially adapt to or respond to the presence of the experimental strategy…Most professional investors, hedge funds, investment institutions and banks prefer to test(backtest) trading strategies in simulation before "going live" with funds at risk. They have compared two important but distinct methods for evaluating a trading strategy: backtesting and Interactive Agent-Based Simulation (IABS). Both strategies are implemented in their open-source ABIDES framework. Question Investigate the impact of a large market buy order by requiring agent to place market buy order sized at 200% of best ask size. This experiment is repeated 100 100 times at different times of day (so statistics are averaged over 100 100 ). Data Between 09:45:00 - 09:53:15 (100 \times 5 \ sec.) 09:45:00 - 09:53:15 (100 \times 5 \ sec.) with order placed every 5 \ sec. 5 \ sec. providing 100 100 buys and 100 100 sells. Agents Experiment Agent acts by a candidate trading strategy. Exchange Agent maintains the order book data Market Replay Agent place limit orders scheduled by historical order book data Market Impact Results Backtest Agent-Based Simulation Tucker Hybinette Balch, Mahmoud Mahfouz, Joshua Lockhart, Maria Hybinette, and David Byrd. How to evaluate trading strategies: single agent market replay or multiple agent interactive simulation? arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.12010 , 2019. ↩
docs.title: Evaluate A Trading Strategy
